message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings, including slanted eyes, small ears, and a flattened nasal bridge, are consistent with those seen in Down syndrome, which is caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21. None of the other options match these specific findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings in Figures A-C suggest Down syndrome which is associated with trisomy 21. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy is associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, and trisomy 18 is associated with Edwards syndrome, but none of these have the specific findings shown in the figures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings in Figures A-C (upward slanting palpebral fissures, flat nasal bridge, and small low-set ears) are classic features of Down syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 can cause DiGeorge syndrome with different features. Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome with distinct facial features, but not the ones observed in this patient. Trisomy 18 can cause abnormalities such as clenched fists and rocker-bottom feet, but not the facial features observed in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Figures A-C show characteristic physical findings of Down syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21. Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, but the physical findings in this case are not characteristic of that condition. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which has different physical findings. Trisomy 18 is associated with a different set of physical abnormalities, including clenched hands and rocker-bottom feet.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has findings consistent with Down Syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 is associated with DiGeorge Syndrome, which has different clinical features. Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can result in fetal alcohol syndrome, which also has different clinical features. Trisomy 18 is associated with characteristic facial and hand deformities, as well as severe intellectual disability and organ abnormalities that are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings in Figures A-C are consistent with Down syndrome, which is caused by Trisomy 21 - the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, and trisomy 18 causes Edward syndrome, none of which match the given findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings in Figure A suggest a flattened nasal bridge, which is a common feature of Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21). Figure B shows an epicanthal fold, which is also a common finding in Down Syndrome. Figure C shows a single transverse palmar crease, which is also frequently found in individuals with Down Syndrome. None of the other options listed have these specific findings associated with them.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings illustrated in the figures suggest the patient has Down syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, while maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy may cause fetal alcohol syndrome. Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, has a different set of physical findings such as low-set ears, small jaw, and clenched fists.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings in Figures A-C suggest the patient has Down syndrome, which is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, and trisomy 18 causes Edwards syndrome, which has different physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings illustrated in Figures A-C match the typical features of Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21) such as flattened facial features, upward slanting eyes, and small ears. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge Syndrome. Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy may cause fetal alcohol syndrome. Trisomy 18 presents with low birth weight, small head, and clenched fists.
